## Biography

[![1776 Project](https://www.wikitree.com/photo.php/thumb/e/e9/1776_Project_Images-2.png/50px-1776_Project_Images-2.png)](https://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Project:1776)

Private Peter (Maurer) Mowery served with Augusta County Militia, Virginia Militia during the American Revolution.

Peter Mowery was born in Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania on the 15th of September 1760, where he lived only a few years prior to his family's move to Augusta County, Virginia.

In the fall of 1780, Peter entered the Army of the United States as a drafted militia man in Augusta County, Virginia. He was enrolled with Captain Hays, in a company commanded by Captain Thomas Smith, who he believed was attached to a Regiment commanded by Colonel Campbell. A short time before the Battle of Guilford he joined the Continental Army under General Nathanael Greene and was in the Battle of Guilford on 15th March 1781.

Peter resided in Augusta County, Virginia for ten or twelve years after the war. He then moved to Sullivan County, Tennessee where he lived about one year, then he moved to Knox County, Tennessee where he lived until he died. Peter filed for an invalid's pension for his service during the American Revolution from Knox County in 1833. He was pensioned at the rate of $20 per annum, commencing 4th March 1831.

He was lastly married 4th May 1829 in Knox County to Sophia Clapp. There is no evidence of children born to the couple. His will was dated 16th June 1838 and presented for probate in February 1840.

## Will

I Peter Mowery being of sound and perfect mind and memory do make and publish this my last will and testament in manner and form following  
First, I give and bequeath unto **my beloved wife Sophia** the land in the following boundary beginning on the east side of Roseberry Creek on the beach of said-creek near a pond in the field then a straight line to Littles and my corner at the crop fence then with said crop fence to the road thence down the road to said creek thence Lip the creek to the beginning including my dwelling house and Out buildings. I further give and depose to my said wife my horse plough and gearing. I further give to my wife the privilege of getting timber of my other land for firewood and fencing and building. The named property I have bequeath to my wife in her widowhood and then to go to my other heirs. I further give and devise to my said wife three hundred dollars, all my household property, my kitchen furniture, likewise the crop that is now growing. The above named money with my household and kitchen furniture I bequeath to my said wife forever. I likewise give to my wife one cow and calf.  
I also give and bequeath to my three sons, Samuel, Lewis and Moses the remainder of my land to be, divided equally between them.  
I give to **my daughter Sophia Gilbreath** fifty dollar.  
I give to **my daughter Anna White** fifty dollars.  
I give to **my daughter Agnes White** dollars.  
I give to **my daughter Elizabeth Foust** fifty dollars.  
I give to **my daughter Jane Low** fifty dollars.  
I give to **my son John's widow Patsy Mowery** fifty dollars.  
I give to **my son Samuel** fifty dollars.  
I give to **my son Lewis** fifty dollars  
I give to **my son Moses** fifty dollars.  
I give to **my grandson, Jackson Mowery**, twenty-five dollars.  
I give to **my grandson, Hazard Mowery**, twenty-five dollars.  
If at my demise there should not be a Sufficiency of money on hand, it is my will that my children and grand children less in proportion to the amount first given to each.  
I hereby appoint Martin B. Carter sole executor of this my last will and testament hereby revoking other wills by me made.  
In witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and affixed my seal the 16th day of June 1838.  
The name of Martin B. Carter enterlined before signed.  
Signed sealed and delivered by the above named Peter Mowery to be his last will and testament in presence of Joseph Stewart and Winston Carter.  

-   -   -   -   -   Peter Mowery {seal}

## Research Notes

[Peter White](https://www.wikitree.com/wiki/White-68862), who married to Peter Mowry's daughter Anna, undoubtedly had a brother James White, who married Peter Mowry's daughter, **Agnes Mowery**, by bond dated 20 July 1801 with the same Samuel Brooks as surety on his marriage bond in Knox County, Tennessee. It appears an A. White attested to their bond.[\[1\]](https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:939Z-Y895-SD?i=789&cc=1619127 "https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:939Z-Y895-SD?i=789&cc=1619127") The 1820[\[2\]](https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:33SQ-GYBZ-C7B?i=28&cc=1803955&personaUrl=%2Fark%3A%2F61903%2F1%3A1%3AXHLJ-45L "https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:33SQ-GYBZ-C7B?i=28&cc=1803955&personaUrl=%2Fark%3A%2F61903%2F1%3A1%3AXHLJ-45L"), & 1830[\[3\]](https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:33SQ-GYBC-9HQV?i=87&cc=1803958&personaUrl=%2Fark%3A%2F61903%2F1%3A1%3AXHG2-XG9 "https://www.familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:33SQ-GYBC-9HQV?i=87&cc=1803958&personaUrl=%2Fark%3A%2F61903%2F1%3A1%3AXHG2-XG9")census indicates the White brothers may have lived in a neighborly fashion in Jackson County, Tennessee.

Mr. Schneider cited the following documents that link Lewis Mowrey to Peter Maurer and Peter Maurer to John Peter Maurer and Anna Sophia Germann: Christening of John Heinrich Maurer, September 20, 1753, Trapp Lutheran Church, Philadelphia County, Pennsylavania; Will of John Heinrich (Henry) Maurer, Probated July 1833, Augusta County, Virginia; Will of Peter Mowery, Probated February 3, 1840, Knox County, Tennessee. Mr Schneider also cites the Revolutionary War pension application of Peter Mowery. -   FamilySearch GWKF- Use with extreme caution! (This is because German boys almost always were baptized with the first name Johannes (or Johann, abbreviated Joh). German girls were baptized Maria, Anna or Anna Maria. (This tradition started in the Middle Ages.) This means a family could (and commonly did) have five boys with the first name Johann.)
